Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Increasing charge separation and extraction by ferroelectric polymer induced persisting electric-field for efficient organic solar cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to boost the efficiency of organic photovoltaic devices to over 15% by eliminating the major energy loss channels. The approach is to apply an ultrathin ferroelectric layer at the organic/electrode interface to induce a strong electric field into the organic semiconductor layer for efficient charge separation and extraction. With this unique structure, there will be no need to apply an external field to have the electric-field-induced charge extraction persist.

Intellectual Merit
This project provides a transformative device design that promises to increase the efficiency of organic photovoltaic devices potentially to the thermodynamic limit. The ferroelectric polymer is a universal dual function interfacial layer for both low- and high-work function surface modifications. Further, this research will bring new fundamental insight to the physics of charge photo-generation, collection, and the origin of the open circuit voltage in organic photovoltaic devices.

Broader Impacts
New fundamental understanding regarding the influence of a strong electric field on charge dissociation and extraction will establish the theoretical base for new applications in electric field-controlled electronic devices, including organic light emitting diodes, excitonic solar cells, high speed photorefractive polymers, organic bistable memory, organic photodetectors, organic transistors, and multiferroics. This research will support outreach activities for students diversified in age, gender, and ethnicity. This platform of learning, which particularly targets high school students, will encourage students to consider careers in the energy conversion engineering field and provide the PI the experience necessary to develop into a stellar teacher-scholar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project started with research in understanding of ferroelectric dipole in enhancing the charge extraction in bulk heterojunction organic solar cells, and migrated to another hybrid material, organic-inorganic halide perovskites, which were thought to be ferroelectric.

This is a very innovative project which has resulted in many important discovery in the organic and hybrid solar cell field.  To name a few of them, we have discovered the gradient bulk heterojunction to reduce the bimolecular charge recombination, synthesis of ferroelectric nanoparticles for the first time, giant switchable photovoltaic effect using organic-inorganic hybrid perovskite materials, a large open circuit voltage over 100 V in lateral structure perovskite solar cells, and the surprising passivation function of sodium ions from sodium-containing glass.  We introduced hybrid perovskites for synapse devices for the first time which paves the way for future neuromorphic computation. We invented the first efficient single crystal perovskite solar cells by growing perovskite singly crystal on top of ITO directly.

This project also resulted in great technology progress and boosted the efficiency of solar cell to record value of the time many times.  For example, we brought passivation concept into hybrid solar cells for the first time to boost the efficiency of p-i-n   structure perovskite solar cells to 16% in 2014, and 18% in 2015, 21% in 2017. These are all records of the time.  We incorporated Cl using a multiple-cycle spin-coating process to generate ultra-large grains using non-normal grain growth mode. We invited a lamination method to fabricate perovskite solar cells without using any vacuum process.

This is a very productive project. This project have resulted in 38 peer-reviewed publications. Most of them are published in top-notch journal such as Nature family journals. Over 20 oral presentations, and over 10 poster presentations have been presented by the PI and advisees to dissimilate the results of this project.  This project also supported eight PhD candidates in part, and the participation of three undergraduate researcher, one teacher-undergraduate student pair. Three PhD students received the prestigious MRS graduate student awards, the highest honor for graduate students in material field, among them two students received the gold medals. All the alumni either became professors in academy or joined industry after graduation.
